instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMCâ€™s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.SMC_TCK: What is SMC_TCK? SMC_TCK is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TDI: What is SMC_TDI? SMC_TDI is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TMS: What is SMC_TMS? SMC_TMS is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.SMC_TDO: What is SMC_TDO? SMC_TDO is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0V
threads.message:
Hi,

On this board, initially <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> were shorted (voltage was 2.6V then). I had to remove SMC to figure it out, which I soldered back, but still <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> was at 0V.

So I have now:
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> : 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> : 0V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL> : 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>  : 3.4V

Should I replace the SMC, or are there other checks to be done before?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0V
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>1V2_S5_SMC</SIGNAL>.
Test with known good SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0V
threads.message:
With old SMC on <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> in diode mode I have 0.52V; with brand new one I have 0.51V.
Otherwise still 0V under power

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0V
threads.message:
SMC must generate that voltage.
Check all voltages on <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> (2 OF 2), page 37.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0V
threads.message:
Here they are:
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> : 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_WAKE_L</SIGNAL> : 3.1 V
<SIGNAL>SMC_CLK32K</SIGNAL> : 0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_EXTAL</SIGNAL> : 0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_XTAL</SIGNAL> : 0.4V
VBAT, VDD (L5001-1) : 3.4 V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> : 0V
VDDA  (L5001-2) : 3.4 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> : 3.3V
<SIGNAL>GND_SMC_AVSS</SIGNAL> : 0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_TCK</SIGNAL> : 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_TMS</SIGNAL> : 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_TDO</SIGNAL> : 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_TDI</SIGNAL> : 3.4V

Seems OK?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0V
threads.message:
Try another SMC.
Be sure to solder it properly...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0V
threads.message:
This is the photo where the SMC should stand. There were some liquid damage, so I cleaned it but now there are stained conductive traces quite close to the soldering balls. Do you think it is manually feasible to solder an SMC here? Or there are hidden shorts when the SMC is in place and it is the reason why I don't manage to have it working?

I tested all the voltages from the previous post directly on the balls and it is ok, the traces are fine

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0V
threads.message:
I can't imagine how did you scratch the board to let the traces uncovered in such way.
You should be able to solder another SMC using 0.3mm balls.

You can't get <SIGNAL>1V2_SMC</SIGNAL> directly on the pads; this voltage is generated by SMC itself, for internal use.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0V
threads.message: Yesterday I watched a video from Louis, "How not to replace an SMC". He mentioned that SMCs should be taken only from donor boards, because new chips were not programed. This was 7 years ago. I bought the new SMC I used for this board on Aliexpress last year. Is it still the case that new SMC chips are just sold "empty"? This may explain it does not work?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0V
threads.message:
Ooops, didn't expect such error; you didn't specify have used new chip.
Get the SMC from donor 00165 board; is the better election.
Anyway, you can use one from other <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2013-2017, or <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>.
You can easily reflash it, once booted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0V
threads.message:
Ok, learning every day!
Very good to know that I can use SMC from older boards at least for testing.
I have another question about this board. As I mentioned in the first post I have <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> : 0V but also <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0V. Am I correct that <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0V is another issue not linked with the SMC? My understanding is that SMC and <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> should both start at the same time, with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> reaching 8.2V, then when they communicate <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 8.6V, true? If so I have another problem with this board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 0V
threads.message:
SMC needs only <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> to start.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> will be adjusted to correct value once SMC can talk with <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.
